data.title: Test: workbench.action.focusActiveEditorGroup Command
data.body:
Test for #11897
- [x] Any OS @jrieken 

Complexity: 1

The `workbench.action.focusActiveEditorGroup` command was added that focuses the most recently active/focused editor group. This enables the implementation of custom keybindings that toggle focus between viewlets or panels without hiding them. For example:

``` js
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
                            "when": "!terminalFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.focusActiveEditorGroup",
                            "when": "terminalFocus" }
```

data.title: Test: New terminal commands
data.body:
Test for #12572, #6603

Complexity: 1
- [x] Windows @chrmarti
- [x] Linux or macOS @kieferrm 

The following commands were added:
- `workbench.action.terminal.scrollUpPage`: Scrolls the terminal 1 page up
- `workbench.action.terminal.scrollDownPage`: Scrolls the terminal 1 page down
- `workbench.action.terminal.clear`: Clears the terminal, moving the prompt line to the top of the new buffer

data.title: Toggle Integrated Terminal keyboard shortcut not working (backtick vs single apostrophe)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.3 (5be4091987a98e3870d89d630eb87be6d9bafd27, 2016-09-22T08:40:08.699Z)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 Linux x64 4.4.0-38-generic
- Keyboard layout: English UK / GB
### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press `CTRL+P`
2. Type `>view integrated terminal`
3. Observe the keyboard shortcut for this command. It appears to be `CTRL+`` (note backtick not single apostrophe)
4. Execute listed keyboard shortcut
### Expected result:

Listed keyboard shortcut toggles the integrated terminal
### Actual result:

Listed keyboard shortcut does not do anything (anything visible??). Instead I found the keyboard shortcut, `CTRL+'` works (single apostrophe not backtick).

data.title: Test: TypeScript version selector
data.body:
Tests https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11772
- [x] any OS @Tyriar 

Complexity: 2
- create a new workspace
- install typescript@1.8.10 in it
- open VS code on the workspace
- open the workspace settings (due to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12679)
- create a TS file
- You should see a message box informing you about a version mismatch:
- Select Use Workspace
- Ensure that the settings file get updated pointing to the local tsserver
- remove the setting
- reload window
- this time select Use Bundled
- ensure that a settings contain a `"typescript.check.workspaceVersion": false`
- remove the setting
- reload the workspace
- open the user settings (due to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12679)
- open ts file
- this time select 'Never Check for Workspace Version'
- ensure  that a user setting  `"typescript.check.workspaceVersion": false` got created.
- remove the setting
- reload and open TS file
- select Close
- reload again
- you should again see the message.

data.title: Settings API doesn't work if no .vscode folder exists
data.body: Use the settings API on a fresh workspace (one that has no .vscode folder). Observer that the setting is not stored in a .vscode/settings.json file. The call is simply a NOOP.

data.title: Support Other Markdown Variants
data.body:
Hello, it would be nice to be able to select support for other markdown in the viewer, other than common-markdown.

I personally would like to see: bitbucket markdown supported, they actually escape angle brackets < >, so it's nice keeping them in if you're just reading the text format.

In github markdown and common-markdown angle brackets must be escaped which can make for some ugly plain text reading. If not escaped, the text becomes invisible since it's incorrectly taken to be an html tag.

Thank you!

data.title: Too hard to tell which extension is giving errors/warnings/info messages in the Problems window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install a bunch of extensions that add messages to the Problems window (warnings/errors/info).
2. Open some workspace that gives messages.

Bug#1: For extensions that don't include their output with the name of the extension, like "[css]" or "[Spell Checker]" it's too hard to tell which extension is causing the message. For example, people have complained about our C/C++ extension giving error messages, when it's another C++ extension and the user has to manually disable every possible extension to figure out which is causing the error message.

Bug#2: And I can't filter based on the extension.

Maybe all extensions should include an identifier with their messages?

Bug#3: In general, it'd be great if I could more easily tell which extension is providing a feature. For example, when I do "Format Code" with multiple format providers installed, I have no idea which one is actually be used. If VS Code could add the name of the extension handler, such as "Format Code [C/C++]" that would be really great. If you think this is too annoying for user who don't care, having optional diagnosis mode/setting would be nice. People have reported bugs for the wrong extension, because they didn't know another extensions was actually handling the functionality, particularly when an existing extensions adds capabilities in an update and it causes another extension from not being executed.

data.title: Test: Yeoman vscode extension generator
data.body:
Tests #10136
- [x] Windows - @ramya-rao-a
- [x] Linux - @octref
- [x] Mac OS - @roblourens 

Complexity: 3
### Setup
- run npm install -g yo generator-code
### Test TS extension
- run yo code
- create a TS extension
- in the generated code verify that:
  - the code compiles and Ctrl+Shift+B works
  - errors are detected while you type
  - code complete works (for vscode & es6 features)
  - no DOM is available
- test that you can launch the extension
- test that you can debug the extension
- test that you can execute the extension test cases
### Test JS extension
- same as the TS extension but for a JS extension (minus building and TS error reporting)
- in addition test that eslint works correctly (for example add unused var). 
- if eslint extension is not installed vscode should recommend it.

data.title: Expose API to know current theme (light/dark)?
data.body: I'd like to propose that the API which is used to determine whether the current theme is light/dark be made public (if possible) so that extensions can use it to style their components. I've felt the need for this while redesigning the [git history](https://github.com/DonJayamanne/gitHistoryVSCode) extension where the plugin itself is hosted within a webview, and thus can't access the parent's classes to determine whether the vscode editor has dark or light theme.

data.title: 'osx' is used as the name for the Mac platform settings, should we consider using 'mac' or 'macos'

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
'osx' is used in settings and schema:
terminal.external.osxExec
terminal.integrated.shell.osx
launch.json
tasks.json
With the Apple switch to "macOS" and the release of Sierra 10.12, should we consider using 'mac' instead and deprecating 'osx' after some number of releases?

data.title: Reconcile file changes between restarts
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a git repo. Do a commit in `master` branch with two files, `hello.ts` and `README.md`.
2. Make branch `test`, remove `hello.ts` and commit.
3. Switch back to `master` and open the project in VSCode. Open both files.
4. Close VSCode. 
5. `git checkout test`
6. Reopen project in VSCode.
7. Although `hello.ts` is not there, it is present in Open Editors, Tabs and Quick Search:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/18845602/39bedf26-83d7-11e6-9380-bdbbd95ba6fb.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/18845644/5d8403d2-83d7-11e6-967a-8daedfca7e65.png)

Trying to open `hello.ts` will show Error, but I think VSCode should store branch info in cache and check against it in startup.

data.title: Debugging node w/ source maps in linked code in node_modules doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use `npm link` to link to a dependency in a node app
2. Put a debugger statement in code in the dependency
3. Debug the node application with `"sourceMaps": true`

The debugger pauses on this stack frame:

```
(anonymous function) <error: base path missing>
```

Clicking on the frame:

```
Source Unknown: Source is not available
```

Switching to `"sourceMaps": false` in launch.json shows the code/break point correctly (but of course no source map). I do this pretty often and it used to work so this seems like a regression issue.

Seems like this kind of error should pretty much never happen, even if there's a problem with the source map, the compiled JS should show per https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/issues/23

data.title: Terminal crashes on startup
data.body: OS X Run vscode out of source Have the terminal open Notice exceptions in console I do not get these exceptions when running the bulit vscode version

data.title: Feature flag/setting for Panels in Activity Bar buttons UI
data.body:
The new UI to switch to a particular panel is a good step forward, but it needs more cooking and at the same time we want to get feedback. Therefore add a setting for enabling the new UI, the setting should be off by default.

The plan is that we announce the feature in the release notes and invite users to provide feedback.

data.title: background extension is not uninstallable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the "background" extension.
2. Uninstall it.
3. Restart VS Code.

Bug: The background is still modified from the background extensions, even though the settings are gone and it says the extension is uninstalled. It seems like the extensions install makes some permanent change that isn't reversible.

data.title: Only absolute urls are supported
Test: Inform users that they are running a patched version
data.body:
Test for #12021 
- File bugs against alex
- [x] Linux @joaomoreno 
- [x] Windows @bpasero 
- [x] OSX @sandy081 

Complexity - 3

Please check in the console that you don't see any warning on startup.

The idea is simple:
- in `product.json` there is a `checksums` field.
- all the files mentioned in there will be checked
- this is not a security feature, but a user awareness feature
- our premise is that end users end up with modified bits on disk and are unaware of it
- we then spend a lot of time to debug their issues and oftentimes it turns out they don't occur in out-of-the-box versions

Please check:
- copy somewhere safe `workbench.main.js` and `workbench.main.css`
- modify either one of the files
- open a new vscode window
- you should see a popup
- the text and buttons should make sense.
- the title adds "[Unsupported]" or something like that
- the feedback widget contains two more sentences of information
- restore the safe copies, check that the message doesn't show anymore
- the More information fwlink is not yet active in the website --> https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/607
- edit the files again
- click the don't show again, see that we don't pop up again but the title still shows unsupported

data.title: Test extension engine compatibility
data.body:
Test for #11573
- [x] Any OS @mousetraps

Complexity - 3

Here you verify if VS Code lets you install / update the extension version compatible to the current VS Code.
### Set up

**Note:** Have the latest `VSCE` installed
- Make sure you can publish an extension. Ref - http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/tools/vscecli
- Use the [sample test extensions](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/extension-deps-sample)
- This repo has 3 extension packs (1, 2, 3) which are already published
- Use these extensions for testing following scenarios (You can also come up with your own if you want to  :) )
- Do play around with following property in `package.json` for testing different scenarios

```
"engines": {
        "vscode": "^1.0.0"
    }
```

**Note:** Publishing the extension takes a while to get reflected in the market place.
### Installing the compatible version
- Make sure the latest version of extension you are installing is not compatible with current VS code version. And one of the older versions is compatible. Use the above engines-->vscode property and publish accordingly.
- Installing this extension should install the version compatible to the current VS Code.
### Updating the compatible version
- Make sure that Extensions view does not show the above extension as outdated even if it has a newer version which is not compatible.
- If there a new version which is compatible then this should be shown as outdated (Update action is enabled).
- Updating this extension, updates to the latest version compatible
